tip.title: Custom user account
tip.para: If you do not want to use the default admin account to access the &dashboard;, create a custom user account with administrator privileges. Refer to for more details.

sect1.para: The dashboard user interface is graphically divided into several blocks: the utility menu in the top right-hand side of the screen, the main menu on the left-hand side, and the main content pane.

sect1.title: Utility menu
sect1.para: The top right-hand side of the screen contains a utility menu. It includes general tasks related more to the dashboard than to the &ceph; cluster. By clicking the options, you can access the following topics:

listitem.para: Change the dashboard's language interface to: Czech, German, English, Spanish, French, Indonesian, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Polish, Portuguese (Brazilian), and Chinese.
Tasks and notifications
View the documentation, information about the REST API, or further information about the dashboard.
User management and telemetry configuration.

note.para: For more detailed command-line descriptions for user roles, see .

listitem.para: Log in configuration; change the password or sign out.

sect1.title: Main menu
sect1.para: The dashboard's main menu occupies the left-hand side of the screen. It covers the following topics:

listitem.para: Return to &dashboard;'s home page.
View detailed information about hosts, inventory, &mon;s, services, &osd;s, cluster configuration, &crushmap;, &mgr; modules, logs, and monitoring.
View and manage cluster pools.
View detailed information and manage &rbd; images, mirroring, and &iscsi;.
View and manage &ganesha; deployments.

note.para: If &ganesha; is not deployed, an information notice appears. See .

listitem.para: View and manage &cephfs;s.
View and manage &ogw;'s daemons, users, and buckets.

note.para: If &ogw; is not deployed, an informative notice appears. See .

sect1.title: Content pane
sect1.para: The content pane occupies the main part of the dashboard's screen. The dashboard home page shows plenty of helpful widgets to inform you briefly about the current status of the cluster, capacity, and performance information.

sect1.para: In &dashboard;, you often work with lists—for example, lists of pools, OSD nodes, or RBD devices. All lists will automatically refresh themselves by default every five seconds. The following common widgets help you manage or adjust these list:

sect1.title: Dashboard widgets
sect1.para: Each dashboard widget shows specific status information related to a specific aspect of a running &ceph; cluster. Some widgets are active links and after clicking them, they will redirect you to a related detailed page of the topic they represent.

tip.title: More details on mouse over
tip.para: Some graphical widgets show you more detail when you move the mouse over them.

sect2.title: Status widgets
sect2.para: Status widgets give you a brief overview about the cluster's current status.

listitem.para: Presents basic information about the cluster's health.
Shows the total number of cluster nodes.
Shows the number of running monitors and their quorum.
Shows the total number of OSDs, as well as the number of up and in OSDs.
Shows the number of active and standby &mgr; daemons.
Shows the number of running &ogw;s.
Shows the number of &mds;s.
Shows the number of configured &iscsi; gateways.

sect2.title: Capacity widgets
sect2.para: Capacity widgets show brief information about the storage capacity.

listitem.para: Shows the ratio of used and available raw storage capacity.
Shows the number of data objects stored in the cluster.
Displays a chart of the placement groups according to their status.
Shows the number of pools in the cluster.
Shows the average number of placement groups per OSD.

sect2.title: Performance widgets
sect2.para: Performance widgets refer to basic performance data of &ceph; clients.

listitem.para: The amount of clients' read and write operations per second.
The amount of data transferred to and from &ceph; clients in bytes per second.
The throughput of data recovered per second.
Shows the scrubbing (see ) status. It is either inactive, enabled, or active.
